Award.AwardTitle: Microwave Activated Heterogeneous Oxidation Catalyst: A New Paradigm for Rapid, Energy Efficient Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation will support the research program of Professor Albert Stiegman at Florida State University. Dr. Stiegman and his students will carry out studies targeting the development of microwave absorbing catalytic materials that will be tested in partial oxidation catalysis reactions driven by microwave energy. The goal of this work is to obtain the fundamental understanding needed to implement energy efficient catalytic process routes taking advantage of the local microwave heating of the catalytic surface. In addition to the examination of a range of spinel structured oxides with high microwave absorption cross sections, nano particles of gold and other noble metals will be investigated in this context. The research will train students in this broadly interdisciplinary area, which includes synthesis, materials characterization, spectroscopic studies, and catalytic evaluation. Fundamental understanding obtained in this work will impact the design of more efficient and energy conserving catalytic process chemistries. Graduate and undergraduate research students will be recruited to the research team through the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The final phase of this project focused on the concluding a study of the microwave driven catalysis of the aryl Claisen rearrangement of allylphenylether (APE) over nano-scale magnetite catalyst. Two products were formed, the expected Claisen product of of allylphenol (AP), and the cyclization  of that product to create 2,3-dihydro-2-methylbenzofuran. The primary scientific goals of this and the earlier studies carried out in this program is to understand the effects of microwave on heterogeneously catalyzed reactions. Specifically, we wish to understands whether microwave radiation will increase the rate of a catalyzed reaction above what it would be under convective heating. In addition, we also wish to investigate whether the microwave driven reaction will change the product distribution (i.e. selectivity) of the reaction. To determine this, identical reactions were run in parallel under microwave and thermal conditions. From a detailed kinetic analysis it was found that the microwave reaction was significantly faster, by close to an order of magnitude. Moreover, the formation of the cyclization product was vastly favored in the microwave where kinetic analysis indicate that it occurs rapidly at the surface. What is not yet fully determined is whether the microwave is merely heating the magnetite surface to an extremely high temperature, which accelerates the reaction or whether there are microwave specific processes that are active. The obtain a better understanding of this, we are modeling the heat transfer processes that occur to obtain an estimate of the temperature of the catalyst.  The determined temperature will be used in the Arrhenius expression to estimate what the thermal rate would be at that temperature and compare it to the rate in the microwave.

 

This study is commensurate with the stated Intellectual Merit of the Proposal in that it achieves a fundamental understanding of how heterogeneous catalysts operate and using this to realize more efficient catalysts and catalytic processes is essential to the goal of energy efficiency and environmental responsibility in the chemical industry.   It also addresses the Broader Impact state in the proposal in that, as fundamental studies of catalytic processes are driven by both energy and environmental needs.,  the project train future members of the scientific community to address chemistry-based problems that have significant environmental and social impact. This achieves one of the primary goals of graduate education: to educate young researchers who will become instrumental in solving future problems. Work on this specific part of the project has resulted in two PhD.s granted.
